Award.AwardTitle: Colloidal membranes and assembly of heterogeneous 2D materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: Amphiphilic molecules consist of water loving and oil loving components that are permanently linked to each other, thus frustrating bulk separation. When added to water these molecules self-assemble into membranes, thin flexible sheets with remarkable properties that play an essential role in biology, physics, and material science. It is commonly believed that the antagonistic nature of the amphiphilic molecules is an essential requirement for membrane assembly. In this proposal PI will study a fundamentally different method for assembly of colloidal based membrane-like materials. Assembly of the novel colloidal membranes takes place in a simple mixture of chemically homogeneous filamentous viruses, which have the shape of billiard cues, and polymers, which resemble billiard balls. Besides providing fundamental insight into universal aspects of all membrane-like materials, results will also describe a new and easily scalable process for assembly of rod-like nanoparticles into novel nanostructures that could act as efficient photovoltaic devices. The PI's research and education plans are seamlessly joined together through their mutual emphasis on visualization techniques and an interdisciplinary approach to science. Specifically, the PI will continue to build upon existing successful collaborations with The Discovery Museum in Action, in order to organize biannual visits to the museum for hands-on demonstrations of various concepts in optical microscopy and materials science. The PI will also extend connections with the local elementary and middle schools by participating in Science Fairs, by organizing class visits, and hosting students in his laboratory. Finally, the PI will continue to provide opportunities to undergraduate students to pursue research projects and will continue to build upon existing local and national connections in order to recruit students form groups that are underrepresented in STEM fields.

Technical: Colloidal membranes are comprised from a one-rod-length thick liquid-like monolayer of aligned rods that is held together by the osmotic pressure of the enveloping polymer solution. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the fundamental laws that govern the assembly processes of colloidal membranes and to use colloidal membranes as a basis for engineering of a new generation of spatially heterogeneous, shape-changing functional materials. The PI will first use colloidal membranes as a robust platform for assembly of well-defined mesoscopic clusters and macroscopic 2D materials with predetermined heterogeneities. In parallel, the PI will devise new methods to measure the mechanical properties of colloidal membranes, and use this knowledge to engineer shape-changing 3D materials. Colloidal membranes are interesting in their own right as they offer a unique opportunity to organize complex 2D materials on micron scales. Furthermore, although distinct on molecular scales, the continuum deformations of colloidal monolayers and lipid bilayers are described by the same free energy expressions. Thus they provide a unique opportunity to gain insight into universal membrane processes that are mainly determined by the fundamental symmetries of the system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through extensive experimentation we have significantly advanced our understanding of self-assembly processes that are mediated by the membrane-like quasi-two dimensional anisotropic environments. For our experiments we have used colloidal membranes which are one rod-length thick liquid-like monolayers of aligned colloidal rods that are enveloped by non-adsorbing polymers. In one important new direction the project has developed a new microfluidic technology to measure the equation of state of the colloidal membranes which in turn provided important insight into the mechanical properties of these materials. In a complementary direction we elucidated how colloidal membranes mediate assembly and interactions of colloidal rafts, which are membrane embedded finite-sized liquid droplets containing thousands of rod-like colloids. In one advance we have elucidated how shorter rods dissolved at low concentration in a colloidal membrane strongly anchor to membrane-polymer interface. Increasing the concentration of shorter rods leads to an intriguing observation of liquid-liquid two-dimensional phase separation. In another notable and surprising advance we have demonstrated that colloidal rafts can switch between two different conformational state that are characterized by either left- or right-handed twist. Depending on these internal states such switchable rafts can either have short ranged attractive or long-ranged repulsive interactions. At higher concentrations such rafts with conformational degrees of freedom can assemble into a variety of colloidal superstructures with unusual symmetries. Our experimental results have elucidated several pathways of unexpected and surprising complexity. They have inspired development of new theoretical models and have suggested that chirality can be used as a generic mechanism that leads to robust assembly of equilibrium finite-sized structures. The project also had significant broader impacts. It has supported education of three graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow and research of undergradaute students. It has supported extensive outreach and scientific demonstrations to local elementary school in Santa Barbara area as well as mentoring of undergraduate students at California State University who are interested in pursuing graduate education.
